The Learning and Development department is full of compassionate, devoted employees and is being directed by an amazing individual that cares about each one of her learning managers. I highly suggest working for Extra Space, especially L&D! * Competitive pay * Professional management * HUGE growth potential * Paid travel * Bonus potential * Fast paced * Lots of change * Great training * Financial transparency
cons: * Long hours for corporate employees * Potential travel

title: The most amazing place to work
pros: - Great work hours and every Sunday off is the best - Company is changing every day. Getting new advanced reports and systems. - My DM Brian gives us all the tools we need to be successful and has an open door policy which makes me feel I can come to him for anything!! - We have contests every month which enables us to push to meet our goals which our DM makes it fun and interesting.
cons: Health benefits a little pricey.

title: Property Manager
pros: -Get Sundays off -Very organized company -Get your own apartment. Mostly just for managers and not for assistants. -There is decent advancement opportunity, but only if you're a "yes" man/woman - If your manager is cool and you do a very good job(store numbers are good) then they give you a lot more freedom and leniency than others.
cons: -Poor pay -Micromanaged like crazy and upper management spies on you like creeps. For example, when you get a lead from the call center, a timer starts going off on your software so the company knows exactly how long it takes you to follow up with lead. -Have to do all the janitorial work on the property: rake leaves, clean units, clean the office, paint etc. I never really minded doing this, but the problem is you have to keep a walkie on you at all times in case a customer comes to the office and buzzes your walkie in which case you have to stop everything you're doing and go back to the office. Makes it very difficult to get things done efficiently. -The job is very property dependent. I worked at several different properties and if you get stuck with a run down property in a bad area, the job is absolutely horrible. I worked a site where there were break-ins every month, rodent damage, water damage, etc.. Basically just consisted of calling people every other day to tell them that their stuff was ruined or stolen. You're also making collection calls every day and dealing with auctions every month. If you get a nice property in a good area then the job is cake. -You will likely start out as an assistant and be expected to cover practically every store in the region. They won't tell you this up front though. Very difficult thing to do for experienced property managers let alone newbies. The pay sucks when you're just an assistant and don't benefit from getting the free apartment.

title: Assistant Manager
pros: Like working with extended family. You only work with one person the entire day which is to be your manager, but because they are changing and growing as such a fast pace, you may be working with another assistant manager at the same store for training reasons.Management is trained to be top notch, my manager was extraordinary!
cons: Because you work with another assistant manager, there could be much competition. I had an another assistant manager asked me why I took a coffee break. Business model of stores is antiquated. Instead of Assistant Managers, do store customer service and let each store be managed with one person not two. There is not enough work for two people to do the entire day, at times bored, be prepared to clean and do maintenance. Too many chiefs and not enough Indians. There needs to be more female top level managers. The culture is still stuck in the 1970's. Too many males not enough females to management roles. No flexibility when it comes to working hours, hours long, traveling to other stores is expected, most employees who have been there for a time, feel guilty for taking a lunch or break. IF you are going to hire assistant managers, please do not hire someone who worked at Taco Bell and think they will be able to be competent at getting along with other co workers who where hired with diverse working backgrounds. Just does not woek. I saw one manager degrade his assistant manager in front of sub contractors and myself when I was only with the company a few weeks.... not a good thing to see as my first experience and I lost confidence in the company at that moment.

title: Wish I had started with this company 20 years ago.
pros: Quality of life. Coming from a Big Box retailer this company really wants you to love your job. Company Culture. The company stands by its values and their recognition for performance is better than any I have seen in 20 years of retail. Sr Management listens to the feedback from the field and acts on it. I have too many Pros to list. Great Company!
cons: Pay is slightly below the same position in other companies at District Manager level, but you typically work less hours.

title: It‚Äôs a great work culture
pros: Corporate Company with family atmosphere. Great benefit package, Paid time off, awesome management and leadership team. Co workers are awesome. Meeting new people and not micro managed. I really enjoy a fact that corporate asks for our feed back and actually listens to any suggestions and ideas we have.
cons: With the 5 years being part of the ESS Team I haven‚Äôt came across one con towards this company. If I would have to pick something i would like to see memorial and labor day added as a paid off holiday. But that is really a suggestion. Not a con

title: I love working with this team!
pros: There is a real sense of camaraderie on our teams. We have the full support of our management and we are doing meaningful work that is mission critical to the company's future. I like that we have clearly defined career paths and a personal development plan. We are encouraged to work on certifications. I like the focus on team ownership of quality and innovation.
cons: I would like to see more collaboration across departments. More shared vision and goals.

title: Hard Work, No Gratitude
pros: Working to help people thru stressful times makes this job fun for me, new contacts in all kinds of businesses. I had customers who came to just talk after they moved out.
cons: this is a numbers job, if you can hit the metrics, and show up no matter how you look, showered or not, repeating scripts for secret shoppers and begging for google reviews. 2 hours round trip to work, you go where they need you.

title: Core Values/People First
pros: Extra Space Storage treats their employees like real people. Decisions made at the executive level are made with their employees in mind. Revenue and shareholders are important, the people running this business are equally important.
cons: There really isn't a "con" of the job. We provide a excellent service and product to the public but there will always be a small percentage of customers that complain and have unrealistic demands but that's customer service in general.

title: Extra Space Storage overview
pros: -Opportunity to learn facility management -Helps you transition from retail to office work/sales -
cons: istent support from coworker across the country -Guaranteed Sundays off -Relatively relaxed job, depending on your location

title: Amazing Company that Delivers Balance
pros: -Works hard to promote from within, many internal development programs available to all departments -Employee focused, we consider the employee impact when we make decisions -Fair compensation, especially within our industry -Great recognition programs, includes all employees -Company is continuing to grow throughout the US -Seasonal Business, but seasonality allows you to spend time with family during holiday times (slow in winter, busy in summer) -Truly Amazing Executive Leadership, always inspiring
cons: -Low paying industry -Costly Medical benefits, but available to everyone -Some Divisions are very spread out, central US mostly.

title: Great company, lousy department.
pros: Extra Space is a well run machine. The executive team has a solid business strategy and they understand the industry.
cons: Accounting staff of 25+ is disposable. The property accountants are hired as an entry level position and there aren't very many senior positions to grow into. Turnover is very high.

title: Restored Faith on Corporations
pros: Great training! - Benefits - Room to Grow - Positive work environment - great compensation - uniform allowance - amazing point of sale system - easy to understand procedures - team training meetings and classes to help better your career - countrywide database - interoffice Q & A's through sophisticated networking between stores - employee recognition awards and incentives - open door policy with Management.
cons: 30 min lunches seem short - some clientele can be unruly depending on location - other than that there is no real downside to working at ESS !

title: A former hidden gem is now nationally recognized for excellence
pros: A fantastic work environment. Management seems genuinely interested in employee satisfaction. Extra Space genuinely strives to offer customers value for their money and a consistent brand image.
cons: The company is growing fast, which puts increased demand on the employees to maintain high standards. Increased demand can lead to lower morale. Also, as the company grows, there is no guarantee that a very friendly corporate culture will be maintained.

title: A great place to grow your career
pros: Extra Space is the best company I've ever worked for. They are constantly growing which provides many opportunities for promotion. They are always updating their technology to enable us to do our jobs more efficiently. My DM is very supportive and makes sure I have the tools I need to be successful. He doesn't just set expectations, he teaches us how to reach them. His open door policy and positive leadership have helped me to grow along with the company.
cons: The health benefits could be a bit more comprehensive.

title: Really a stepping stone
pros: *Hours you work *Work-life balance *District meetings are OK *Pick up a few new work skills *Its possible to get housing
cons: *Alot of Favoritism *Depending on your district, could be a lot of Backstabbing (fellow co-workers, management, etc.) *For what you get paid for, it's not worth the work. *They entice you with housing but take alot out of your paychecks. *More than likely, Management has never done the work you do.

title: Property Accountant
pros: Extra Space has a great culture where employees are trusted. With adjustable work hours and little micro managing, this is a great company to be a part of. You start out with accruing 3 weeks off which seems either better than or the same as other companies.
cons: Amount of turnover in the accounting department.

title: Want to grow? This isn't the place.
pros: The best reason to work for Extra Space would be job security. As long as you perform and you show up for work, you keep your job. The environment is not great, but you have the option to work from home after proving yourself. The pay is mediocre now but used to be quite competitive... it's still an upgrade for anyone working a retail or restaurant job.
cons: It is very easy to go unnoticed. You can make real sacrifices in your personal and family life and not be recognized. They say you are going to get opportunities because the company is growing but really, they strive to bring outsiders in, instead of promoting from within. Complaints to upper-level executives are often met with no action. The HR department at the NSC (National Sales Center) is constantly changing, this leaves the lower-level employees feeling helpless when major issues arise. Veteran/Active Duty support has been requested for years and has not made any progress, for employees or customers both. The environment at the NSC is quite bland, it starts to feel like a day at the DMV after a couple of hours. There's no gym access, no meal benefits, no activity center to release your wiggles or decompress from your workday. Socializing in the workplace is frowned upon. This is not a team environment. While maintaining the imagery of a team and separating agents into teams, it's very individual driven. Team Leads are often overwhelmed with extra projects that higher leadership should not delegate. In terms of technology, the company has a lot of improvement that needs to be done... including the very software you will use to convert sales. Paid holidays are dwindling.

title: Honesty is not their policy
pros: Not a single good experience.
cons: Required to work through lunches and work off the clock. Raises are minimal if any at all. Policies change frequently with little notice if any. Upper management is not easy to speak with in any situation. Very bad communication.

title: It's pretty casual and easy going
pros: The hours are great and depending on your district or DM it can be a pretty easy and casual job.
cons: Working every saturday, it seems like every other week there a new change as far as policies and duties. Making calls in the required time allow can be stressful. Also some of the people you work with can be lazy. Oh and most importantly, it's all about who you know and who likes you if you want to get promoted.

title: Great Company, Great People
pros: Let start off by saying that there are always growing pains while a company grows and Extra Space has always had the integrity to admit this - so in my book - they are awesome! They were always wonderful to work with - even when working through situations that were not all that wonderful. I always worked with a great team - no matter how district re-aligned.
cons: There will ALWAYS be people that complain! If you think there is a perfect job in this world - shut up, stop wasting your time and ours and go find it! Many different things go into situations at work that end up how we wish they did not. I love self storage - how I can jump right in and make a difference daily. As a whole - after trying out other companies - Extra Space Storage - was the best of them all. The job can be stressful. That is just the nature of the beast.

title: Awesome Career Choice
pros: Work/life balance is beyond amazing. If you are looking for a great place to have a stress free career, this is it.
cons: You will not become a multi-millionaire working here. The wages are low, but the time I get to myself is worth it.

title: Not Just a office job
pros: The hours (out by 6 m-f and 530 on Saturday No Sundays). The pay is good compared to some other storage facilities.
cons: It is not a Con but a FYI... This is not just an office job you have to go out and clean units (sweep, wipe down walls make sure if the customer has not already done so remove all items from the unit. The property is yours to take care of make sure that you get vendors in for landscaping and other maintenance. There is always work to do outside (wiping down doors, sweeping, mopping halls).

title: IT department was a mess, a lot of politics
pros: I had to dig deep on this one...free drinks in the kitchen? Not much else. Some of the people I worked with were really nice, but some of the other BA's I was forced to work with were extremely pretentious.
cons: Pay is hilarious - I've more than doubled my salary in 2 years since leaving. Horrible IT management. Glad I left when I did. It's been 2 years, and still no regrets about leaving!

title: Property Manager
pros: The company culture is to collaborate (ideas, problem-solving, innovating), while much of the work is independent or as a duo on site. Our days are filled with attending to the needs of potential and current tenants and taking care of the property. Both fulfill our commitment to customer service. We get to exercise a wide variety of skills, making each day a little different from the last. Extra Space develops these skills through a nicely structured training program, and supports the learning through a system of district trainers to help you out.
cons: Frustration over aspects of managing a property that are outside of your control.

title: Solid Place to Work
pros: Extra Space cares about you as a person and is very interested in both your career success and personal success. Extra Space does a nice job allowing employees to balance work life and personal life. I feel the company creates a culture of teamwork and I feel almost everyone wants to do the right thing no matter the situation. Extra Space is a good company to work for and employees are generally treated well. People are nice and management is supportive.
cons: Not a lot of cons - could be more flexible with telecommuting or other alternative work schedules, but nothing too bad.

title: Great Company if You are NOT Looking to Advance
pros: Life/work balance, decent pay, company stands by its values from executive leadership to entry-level positions. Customer service oriented.
cons: Advancement opportunities are VERY limited, especially if you are over 40 years of age. They are now open on Sundays for four hours, so you either have your hours reduced to 36/week OR go in to work for four hours on your "day off". Hiring of external district management causes the teams to lose morale and slows production while the new DM goes through their learning curve.

title: Exciting technology, great work/life balance
pros: The development teams are given autonomy to choose the right technology and to pivot and evolve as needed. This leads to exciting opportunities to work on things like cloud-native architecture, Kafka streaming, IoT, new frameworks and CI/CD tools, etc. These career growth opportunities, along with great people and an exceptional work/life balance, are reasons many of our engineers cite for loving their job. IT also offers a well thought-out career guide and a technical career track that parallels the management track.
cons: We've been playing catchup with competitive pay, but many companies are in the same boat. I'm confident we're committed and moving in the right direction.

title: Good to work for but room for improvement for non-management positions
pros: I enjoy that the company is very family oriented. The summer party and Halloween party are always fun for the entire family. It is also nice to have some flexibility of my schedule. We have core hours, but we are not tied to the typical 9-5 schedule. Upper management is honestly concerned about the employees.
cons: Compensation is average for non-management, much of the turnover seems to be compensation related. Our health benefits are average as well.

title: Overall, the National Sales Center is a great place to work!
pros: Awesome monthly incentive for top performers! You'll be working with high caliber people! All the calls are Inbound, so there no prospecting! It's a Fun Place to Work!
cons: It can be stressful to hit your daily quotas! Turnover is high, especially for low performers! If your not a good closer, you won't last very long! Some of the team leads are better than others!

title: I love my job at Extra Space Management!
pros: I go to work every day and feel valued. There are many opportunities to learn and, from what I can tell, advance in this company. Management is respectful and courteous and the culture is very positive.
cons: Extra Space seems to promote from within as much as possible. However, I do not see a clear path for advancement for me at this point.

title: Property Accountant
pros: Extra Space has a great work environment, it is pretty laid back and enjoyable. The people are great to work with, and management is very down to earth and let you "do your thing" without looking over your shoulder. In the accounting department we regularly have fun activities, and have opportunities to get to know each other and build friendships. The company cares about each employee.
cons: There is a considerable turn over in the accounting department.

title: Store Manager
pros: Never the same day twice, great training, fair pay, benefits. Better job than I thought it would be. Best part for me, coming from a retail background- NO NIGHTS!!
cons: Dealing with people going through life transitions is not for everyone. Auctions feel like I am kicking people when they are down at their lowest point. Very sad to see people just like me struggling to financially survive have everything they own sold to the highest bidder-especially when the bids are so low.

title: Amazing Culture
pros: Company has always taken a very proactive interest in its employees well being and constructive enact policies geared to employee well being and work life balance. it encourages employee engagement and reinforces its corporate culture through action and not just talk. Great at hiring from within and encouarging upward mobility.
cons: Lack of diversity at the corporate level. Terrible at retaining and sustaining a reasonable proportion of minority (black) representation. No minority represented at corporate management Level which pretty deplorable.

title: Truly excellent work/life balance
pros: Excellent work/life balance, great culture, exciting technology. As a software engineer, you have so much opportunity for growth and learning here. Everyone is willing to help each other out, within and across teams. Technology is a huge focus for the company and we're always given the resources we need to succeed. It's no surprise to me that we have hardly any turnover on our dev teams. I really enjoy coming to work every day.
cons: Stability of our new core product is a struggle, but at the same time it offers a challenge for us to overcome.

title: Best Company I've Ever Worked For
pros: The support that you get from upper management regarding the job is second to none. I have never worked for a company that consistently SHOWS and VOICES how much they appreciate employees as much as Extra Space does. There are many opportunities to relocate to other states and transfer to other site level positions.
cons: Pay could be better, and opportunity for growth beyond site positions are minimal. Majority of the positions beyond the site are located in Utah.

title: Software Developer
pros: The company is successful, so Job security is mostly guaranteed, plus, they have a hard time hiring so you dont have to worry about getting replaced. The corp office is very nice and my cube has a window overlooking the salt lake valley.
cons: IT is not respected in this company at all. It is hard to get over feeling like a second class citizen in this environment. The technology is antiquated and difficult to support. The management style of the executives is fear and insult based and most people are scared for their jobs or contemplating quitting because they get tired of the insults.

title: Company that cares about its employees in more ways than one.
pros: Work-life balance, competitive pay, incentives, recognition, benefits. I have been able to work my way into multiple positions. The company recognizes talent and skill-sets and helps to hone and improve those skills. Nothing in life is handed to you but if you are willing to work hard and take the steps to improve then this company will back you up 100%.
cons: I have been with Extra Space for almost 7 years and they continue to improve with each area of the company. I cannot think of a negative thing to say or an area of improvement.

title: Great Company
pros: I have been with the company less than a year. Everyone that I have met, from Assistant Store Managers to the CEO, has been excellent. There is a wonderful corporate culture and it is a great environment to work in. Integrity, partnership and hard work are key company values.
cons: In my experience the compensation is somewhat below market. Wages for employees below VP level are not as competitive as other companies. The benefits package is only average, it was cheaper for me to go on my spouse's plan than use our company one.

title: It's all about the Culture!
pros: Wonderful culture here at Extra Space. We really work hard and have fun to drive our metrics. People are the thing that we are most passionate about, and this is reflecting in our culture where we make Extra Space a great place to work.
cons: Site Managers work hard in office and on property! District Managers have a lot to juggle! But everyone works hard to get it all done!

title: Decent job depending on location of your site.
pros: The pros of working with ESS would be definitely be the benefits they offer. They offer accumulating PTO which you can start using as soon as you get hired. Great 4O1k, dental, vision, and life insurance. Medical is on the high side but the coverage it self is good. If your lucky you can get a live on site position. Not all the sites have apartments for the manager but most do. Free rent and utilities if you get to live on site however they will dock your pay 2.00 or more an hour if they give you an apartment.
cons: Like I said in the title the way you feel about this job will depend a lot on the location. Sites with an onsite manager are usually better but that means you will have to play cop 24/7. Some sites are in really bad neighborhoods. You will find your self in constant battles with un desirable tenants that try to live in the storage units. Evictions processes are long and stressful especially in California. You will end up paying a lot of people off to get out of your facility. The company refuses to invest money in security even though they have the resources which has never made a whole lot of since to me. Why wouldn't we do everything possible to keep our tenant's and their belonging's safe? How bad could it really hurt the bottom line to invest in security guards and decent camera systems??? If your lucky enough to work at a site out in the sticks some where with out a whole lot of come and go traffic your job will be wonderful. Inner city areas not so much. And you better hope and pray you like your manager or assistant manager because that is the only other person you will work with. So if you guys don't see eye to eye its extremely uncomfortable and basically your word against theirs if you have to address the problem with management.

title: Site Manager
pros: Hours, Ability to Move Up Based on Your Performance, Great Co-Workers, Able to Help Folks in What Can Sometimes Be a Bad Time for Them, Pride in Your Site
cons: Pay could be a little higher especially for those that take on extra things that are not in there job description. More contests to pay out more bonues

title: Extra Space
pros: Overall it's a great place to work. I've been with the organization for a few years now the moral and work life balance is great. I'm lucky to have a great DM who really works with the staff. The training, support and the perks are still fairly good. They offer bonuses which many companies and overall the company does a good job. The properties are well kept and it's a good working environment.
cons: They have been cutting back a lot and sadly those cuts hit the field employees the most. They cut back on low waged employee bonuses and even gift cards. Granted that these items are perks but on the store level we are first liaison between the customer and management. They've also cut back on staffing budget allowances, and many stores are being left single staffed. This over works staff who are getting paid now as one individual but doing the work of two people. It also causes a danger concern having one individual working alone on a property. The turnover rate for the Assistant Managers are greater than any organization I've worked out previously. Due to low wages for the expectation of work. Another concern. It also makes it difficult for staff to take their hard earned vacations when there is no coverage. In turn this hurts the DM who are now unable to hire the right staff.

title: A solid place to work
pros: The bosses really care about you and always ask what they can do for you to make sure you are doing okay. They encourage you to be open about any feelings you are having personal or professional. They also love growth in the company and encourage you to move up in the company, and are happy when you want to. Everyone in your district is also very wiling and able to give you a hand and help you in any way they can. The job itself is also very interesting, encompassing a lot of different tasks that you have to perform, and there is always something to do, and there are hardly any days where you are bored or you looking for something to do.
cons: One small downside is that you do have to work 8 hour days on Saturday, which is a little vexing, but not too bad. But the main downside of working at Extra Space is the compensation. Sometimes when the days are long and you have 100 things to do while trying to rent to customer's, it does feel like we are inadequately compensated. For instance, I have to pay a lot of different bills every month. I just graduated college and am paying a student loan payment: I pay rent to my brother every month, I have a huge credit card bill, I pay for my phone, car insurance, utilities, etc. Some weeks I am barely squeaking by, and I am not able to put any money away for savings most weeks. For example, If I get into a car wreck, I'll be in a lot of trouble, because I have no way of paying for another car, unless I accrue more debt, which I don't want to do. I know my situation could be a lot worse and I'm not looking for pity, only being transparent. Also I am aware I'm still pretty new to the company. I'm only saying if I got paid just a few more dollars an hour it would save me a lot of worry.

title: Active Facility Management
pros: *Good pay and consistent hours *If you like to be active and keep going at work, this position can give you that *Evenings are free *Good for students that take evening classes after 6pm
cons: *Sometimes communication needs to be more advanced *District Manager is the supervisor, but sometimes they are too busy to assist you, so you rely on others with seniority. This creates an awkward dynamic because the Store Manager isn't really your supervisor, but a higher ranking coworker.

title: Incredibly Mediocre
pros: The people are the best part of working at Extra Space. For the most part my coworkers were some of the best people I have known. Many were humble, kind, selfless. Extra Space does a lot of bragging about how long people tend to work at Extra Space and to an extent they are right. People work there for a long time, but it isn't necessarily because of Extra Space being the best place to work, it is because it is a tolerable atmosphere where people can focus on their family. One thing Extra Space does very well is Work Life balance. These humble people are exactly the type of people that Extra Space likes to employ. People who are humble and sometimes insecure, whose focus is on their family and not on the fact that they could be paid more somewhere else. They are just grateful to have a job. These individuals make great coworkers but can be easily taken advantage of by the company. They do a good job of promoting internally, which creates great opportunity for people who work at Extra Space, though they do this in part because they are not willing to pay the price for outside talent. They have great corporate values. Unfortunately this is overshadowed by the fact that their philosophy and the way they behave are very different. Most of the time the behavior doesn't align with the philosophy. There are a lot of people at Extra Space with good ideas, but the execution isn't great.
cons: The disconnect between managers and their employees is palpable. Software Development Management is involved too much in direction and not enough in managing/coaching employees. They want to be "decision makers" not leaders and managers. Mentorship will have to be found in coworkers, who may not have the time to help as it is not a part of their job description to do so. This is another example of where philosophy splits from behavior. They say they want you to help your team, they say they "Experts Help". Sometimes even when people take the time away from their own tasks to help, they are met by criticism that they aren't doing enough in their own jobs. These metrics that they are measured by are also not very nuanced. You are compared to your peers by number of tasks completed. So remember that task you helped your teammate complete? It didn't really matter in the long run, because he got the credit for it and it was used against you. Your coworkers perception of you is not taken into account in this judgement. So it can feel like you are just a number, not a valued employee. The company is a little too investor friendly in my opinion, meaning they are cheap. Obliviously this affects employee compensation. Their compensation philosophy is to pay people as close to, or below average if they can. They will label this as "Competitive". Their definition of competition is a little funny, because usually you want to be the best, not just in the middle of the pack. You will likely be under paid. "Work/Life balance" is part of your compensation package.

title: Room to grow, but no support
pros: The people who you work with are the best part of working, they all honestly give 100% to help the customer and help other stores.
cons: Most of management will not hear what you have to say. We are all drastically underpaid with a maximum of partial dollar raises. And they say we are sales but we don't get commission. On top of that, instead of paying their current employees a living wage, they will give you a bonus if you get someone else to apply.

title: Pretty good company, would recommend even with cons.
pros: Benefits; medical, dental and vision, friendly atmosphere; you feel heard and included, room for advancement if you're dedicated, allotment is given for shoes and uniforms annually, incentives based on store performance, PTO is usually approved and depending on the district manager you can pick your day off for the week. You are not micromanaged for the most part. Before the pandemic there used to be company meetings/spring kick offs, team building activities, paid lunch mileage to those events. Used to host a company paid xmas party (now just a yearly bonus). The ability to run your store and build some good relationships with customers.
cons: Pay increases are small, taxed in incentives, only 4 paid holidays a year, have to work half day on xmas eve at regular pay, no overtime unless it is approved. If you work overtime, you have to either come in later, leave early or take a longer lunch which I don't believe is fair. If I stay late and miss out on my personal time to benefit the company I should get paid time and a half. The company doesn't like you taking off Fridays, Saturdays or Mondays so your 1 work week day off (besides Sunday) is limited unless you submit PTO (which you earn around 2.31 hours every week). Customers can rent online and with QR codes so why do we have to be at the site on a holiday when they can take care of everything themselves? Why can't we take off any day of the week we want if we are either double covered or can alternate with AM & SM's to make sure at least one is in the office.. Company wants your to get rentals and offers waiving of admin fees, free locks and credits to get the customer to rent that day but that reflects on your financials and you are questioned on how you are selling merchandise and why your waived fees were high etc. and receive coaching and guidance on how to boost those numbers. How do you boost your numbers if you are told to give away the farm? Most of the time the store manager/assistant manager can handle customer issues but if the customer isn't satisfied, it can get escalated and the customer usually gets what they want to retain their business. Customers expect you to bend over backwards for them and they turn around and trash your building that YOU have to clean and maintain. Examples include sweeping, mopping, and waxing floors, and cleaning all hundreds of unit doors by hand. Customer leave behind garbage and furniture that you have to throw away, break down or spend budget money to have a company come remove. You have to visit other competitors and pretend you are looking to get a unit so you can see how you compare to them. This should be done 1-2 times a year. If you visit them and give them your information they will probably remember you if you keep returning and they can most likely find you in their system from previous inquires which can make things awkward. You can receive calls at any time for a customer issue that gets sent to you from the call center. Example: Customer can't enter the building because the door is stuck closed and you have to go to the facility at 11 pm to fix it and end up staying later to make reports and call vendors. You get paid for that time, but as mentioned above, have to cut your time somewhere else.

title: Half and Half:
pros: Good caring team members, always willing to help when needed. No work on Sundays. Same work Days. OT opportunities. Reimbursements for gas.
cons: Listen, when I started this job I was excited, ready to do whatever to be the best. Training: Training could of defiantly been better, after months of working on my own. I am starting to learn there was A LOT, I missed out on, almost seems like being at a disadvantage. When problems arise there is a finger in your face, asking you why you didn't do this correctly. When realistically it came from not being taught correctly the first time or at all. It makes your job 100 times harder when you have to learn something on the spot. It's not fair for someone to feel like they are failing, when they don't know. Work expectations: I don't even know where to start with this one. You are literally, a maintenance man, janitor, a sales man, security, and a office representative. The workload for this job depending where your store is at in terms of progress. Is super unrealistic especially if you are the only person working the site. I have went home with massive headaches, stressing over the expectations of this job that had been put on me at the time. Even curranty there is always a massive "bag" of work, goals, kpi, auctions, google reviews, ect. Hanging over your head, you would like to be able to choose which project or situation seems more dire. But in reality it all needs to be accomplished at once. Or in a very short period of time. Pay: Pay needs to be matching the amount of work that is being put on an employee. Not getting paid enough to do massive amounts of work is frustrating in itself. Promises: Promises coming from management need to be handled more professionally, especially when it effects your life outside of work. Or your bills/money. This is a company that's defiantly not lacking in recourses. It's not fair to give hope on a situation that always seems to be getting put off. Currently I still would like to give things a chance, but I am a human with needs and a life outside of my job. If not I have to take care of myself and my mental health. People are not machines, times are hard in our world right now.

title: Wonderful company to work for!
pros: Extra Space is a company with integrity. They have consistently delivered outstanding performance. They are a growing, thriving company with lots of opportunities. They care about their employees, ask for your best work, and celebrate successes together. It's a great group of people who work hard and have fun.
cons: There are not many cons, management listens and acts upon ideas and improvement areas. With the innovative nature of the company there is a lot of change making it hard to adapt for some employees.

title: Please Don't Waste Your Time
pros: If you need to get 1-5 years on your resume and move on, here is where you want to be. They will not be truthful about anything. No loyalty paid back, all lip service, no long term commitments on their side. So if you need something quick and not long term, here is your spot.
cons: Literally everything. Pay, respect, management, benefits, location, politics, career growth, projects, and did I mention management?

title: District Manager Trainee
pros: Potential for Future Growth, I Started as a Store Manager and Today I'm a District Manager Trainee. Extra Space welcomes and supports high performers who deliver exceptional customer service. In addition to having the ability to set priorities, to separate the relevant from the irrelevant tasks, and then to focus until the job is complete. Overall, with determination, integrity, and for those who aspire to grow, Extra Space delivers on their promise for future growth.
cons: Whirlwind of tasks, prioritizing is key. Many individuals do not see self-storage as a viable career choice, so finding top talent is challenging.

title: Assistant Store Manager
pros: Great hours, wonderful chances to interact with our tenants and to help them become more than just numbers on a spreadsheet. Great team interaction with the rest of our district, creating a very friendly work environment.
cons: Question: Why are so many people slobs, when it comes to leaving drinks, food wrappers, cigarette butts, feces, etc., on the property? Ah, well....

title: Decent work/life balance
pros: Good work / life balance. Decent pay. Decent work schedule.
cons: Store managers do not get to hire there employees. Which can make for a stressful and down right toxic environment when they do not get along with your personality. A "numbers" company so you better stay on top of your numbers or you will be constantly micro managed. Can be stressful at times. You will definitely earn your pay here. No coasting by in this industry. Be prepared to work in all weather types, and environments.

title: Best Place I've Ever Worked
pros: People work hard and truly respect each other. There is room for constructive discussions and yet there is still the commitment to move forward as one company. Never have I worked for a company where the CEO is so engaged with employees and shows courage to share priorities and ask for help from employees. Extremely admirable! I love this place!
cons: Rapid growth and redefinition of who we are beyond the 3 walls and concrete floors. But the reward for hard work is SWEET.

title: Best Kept Secret In Retail...yes I said Retail.
pros: +Live and evangelize a positive work culture that most companies have just left on mission statement board somewhere. +Work Life Balance at all field operational levels. +A business who listens to and responds to the front line employees. +Pay is fair in my experience. +Job is fun. Yes storage is fun. +Your input is required. Yes your opinion matters and be ready to share it. +Highest standards in the storage industry. Our product is superior. +ESS has embraced technology that Blockbuster could have only dreamed of. +Company is genuinely striving to improve all of its processes and attempting to avoid complacency. Never have I encountered a company that sent my son a gift card for Christmas because his Dad worked hard and I couldn't do that without his support. Mind blown. The values and ethics of this organization are above reproach in my experience thus far. If there are 10 companies in all of retail who treat employees with the respect and appreciation Extra Space does, I might call you a fibber. Over 3000 employees, almost 1400 locations and market cap into the billions. Would make you think its a giant Machine who chews employees souls to generate profit. Not at Extra Space. I drank the "Kool-Aid" and it's good. Better yet it is real. Come join me and find out. We need good people like you to take our next steps into a bright wasabi green future.
cons: -I wished I had discovered this industry, and specifically this organization a long time ago. That's it. Anything else that I may not be find completely to my liking is really superfluous and would be me reaching to find something that is displeasing. When you are treated well, what can be that bad?

title: Okay
pros: It's nice and comfortable for the most part. Goals are attatainable. Expectations are usually realistic.
cons: Doesn't matter how hard you work it doesn't make a difference. You can be the top contributer in your area for a goal and they treat you like you always fail at it.

title: Great place to work
pros: Decent pay, No over time, Great communication, benefits package, the people, an atmosphere where you actually accomplish things, It's quite rewarding emotionally because you do generally feel like you are helping people.
cons: Honestly, I haven't really found any cons. Coming from a retail background, I love the more "chill" atmosphere. Even though you wear many hats, you aren't pulled in 50 directions.

title: Great Place To Work At!
pros: I have been with Extra Space for 3 years as a Store Manager. I wish I would have got on board 20 years ago. This has been by far the most rewarding job I have ever had. I have been able to maintain my stores goals at a high level and won a ‚ÄúMission Accomplished‚Äù award 3rd quarter of 2021. This is partly due to my personal work ethic and desire to grow personally. But, mostly due to the support from my DM, DTLS and other Managers that I work with. Every time I have reached out to them with questions or asked for help I have always received an immediate helpful response. My typical day is 50% office work and the other 50% is maintaining the property. Honestly, this can be challenging at times but if you prioritize your day/days you will succeeded. I enjoy the challenge and being able to move around the facility with the many different tasks presented to me. I enjoy coming to work because of the challenge and the opportunity to interact with my customers. It‚Äôs all about connection with the customers and providing them with solutions to their storage needs. What‚Äôs exciting is I have become friends with some of my tenants and have had others return for business. I‚Äôm building relationships and a good reputation in my city. Before you apply with ESS I highly recommend you Google the job responsibilities of the position. I have seen some reviews from past employees and I don‚Äôt think they read them. This company offers you to take responsibility of your store, handing you the keys to manage it and make it succeed. They also give you the tools you need to succeed. This is an office job but a physical one to! I highly recommend Extra Space Storage. It‚Äôs a great and rewarding place to work at!
cons: I have no "Cons" to share.

title: Good times at ESS
pros: Great bonus program incentive for renting units. When hired, you are assigned to the site closer to your home. Great team to work with. Everyone in our district is very knowledgeable and helpful
cons: The payment gap between an assistant manager and store manager is not much. There is not "sick pay" If you get sick it comes out of PTO. While having Sundays off, schedule fluctuates and is submitted by month.

title: Amazing culture!
pros: I have never worked with a better team. Everyone, and I mean everyone is here to help each other. The team welcomed me with open arms and they made me feel like part of the family from day one! After several decades of working, I have finally had my last "first day" of a job. I now have a career with a family that values me and my contribution to the team.
cons: The only con I can think of is having to work every Saturday. It would be nice to be able to have an occasional Saturday off without having to use PTO.

title: Not a Positive Environment
pros: Good starting pay when I started. The hours of operations isn't 24 hours so the latest schedule is 12-8pm.
cons: They change the commission structure constantly to reflect you getting less and less with every change. Benefits are very pricey especially if your looking for a family plan. The moral in the National center is horrible and very negative. The management definitely plays favorites to certain employees and it's obvious who they are.

title: Good Job if you aren't lazy
pros: Great hours, good work life balance. I have been with Extra Space Storage 8 years, 4 as an asst. manager and 4 as a site manager and have worked with many DM's most of whom have had a caring and positive attitude. My current DM makes it clear to me that he has my best interest at heart and helps me to achieve my goals. Good company if you want to learn. They are committed to promoting from within.
cons: Benefits are a bit pricey.

title: I did an internship for them within the past two years.
pros: It was a great environment for learning and growing your knowledge of SOX and learning the skills to create and use tests as controls.
cons: Some of the people there are completely incompetent. They do not pay as much as others in the arena, but overall you will be smarter than most of the people there.

title: South Jordan, Utah Call Center
pros: Good pay and commissions if you are a top sales agent. They try to make fun work environment by playing music and games between calls. Most people working there are nice.
cons: Very stressful work environment. You receive sales updates on every hours. They send you home for part of the day if you are not performing up to their standard. They treat you great if you are top performer, but badly if you don't meet their very high expectations. Very high turnover. Have to work weekends. Benefits are not good.

title: Little to know growth for field employees
pros: At extra space they do trust you to get the job done with out micro managing. Free apartment for managers is always a plus.
cons: There is alot of work they expect you to do that is not in the jobe description. You are expected to do alot of laborious work. Expect to be cleaning outside and in while still maintaining a presentable look for customers.

title: This once WAS a great place to work.....
pros: The people who still remain from what was once a great company are a definite positive. However, those loyal and dedicated people will continue to exit as this company continues to sacrifice them for the sake of the numbers.
cons: This was once a company that recognized and rewarded great performance and lived by their values. Unfortunately, it has lost many great employees over the past few years and has transitioned to an organization that promotes based upon who you know and not how you perform. And though they talk about values, they no longer abide by them. When it's not convenient or it doesn't drive numbers, integrity goes out the window. And there are several recently promoted executives who have had a history of not living the values. CEO Spencer Kirk is a great leader and a great man. Unfortunately, I can only speculate that those immediately below him have to be hiding these types of behaviors from him High level director positions are filled on the basis of political expediency, not on the basis of past performance or experience. People are being promoted into high level positions in fields where they have had no previous experience. The chasm between the field and corporate continues to expand as corporate centralization continues to make Salt Lake an exclusive club that closely guards information and meticulously screens those who apply to be a part of that club.

title: Will be starting my 10th year of employment in a few months.
pros: Extra space takes care of its own. As a company they make sure that we have access to a good health plan, disability insurance, life insurance and paid time off. Districts are very team oriented and the training is good. There is always somone that you can reach out to if you need help.
cons: With only two or three employees per store to run the entire facility it can sometime get challenging making sure that your customers are taken care of the extra space way.

title: So much growth
pros: I've had a lot of opportunities to grow my career at Extra Space, and I recommend the company to anyone who wants the same. I am proud to work at a high-tech innovator within the storage industry. Also I have been impressed with how connected the executive team stays to the larger workforce. They do town hall meetings with all employees several times per year.
cons: Things move fast at Extra Space, and change management is not always perfect. Benefits are a bit more expensive than other companies I've worked for.

title: Could Have Had A Career Here
pros: Every day provided something different!
cons: Management, Pay, Treatment of Employees. It is difficult to express in words the complete and total lack of care and consideration from upper management who were all safe inside their office building while we dealt with the weight of the company. The sales process was egregious, forcing managers to make overpriced sales, and coercing insurance sales. There were so many shady business practices, I felt dirty working there.

title: Wise Career Change
pros: I was in retail for over 30 years, I was looking for a position that would value my management experience. I have enjoyed the slower pace of this business. Other managers in my area have been very helpful in helping me to learn the storage business. My dealings with my DM have been very professional. As one who did a complete career change at my age, Extra Space was a good choice.
cons: In my short time with the company, I have found very few shortcomings.

title: Awesome place to be
pros: Management is very understanding and willing to help you. There are a lot of opportunities for advancement in the company. Great environment to be in overall. There's a lot of great communication and cooperation between the departments as well as from management to the other employees. Very transparent company with likable management and innovative ideas.
cons: The current position I am in is kind of a thankless job, but it doesn't go unnoticed by management. Team work is definitely stressed here, so not a good place if you like working alone on projects.

title: Great company, great leadership, great colleagues
pros: Extra Space is a company with a proven track record in good times and bad. It is led by an executive team that cares about integrity and doing the right thing. After working in four other settings, I've never enjoyed coming to work each day as much as I do at Extra Space. The people I work with are intelligent and professional, but they are also delightful and caring.
cons: A little behind the times with respect to flex-time and remote work options, but headed in the right direction.

title: The best company I have worked for.
pros: Extra Space is a fast paced, challenging work environment. I love the fact you can stay challenged and the job doesn't get boring. There are opportunities to advance. Since the company is always growing, there are many opportunities for process improvement and growth.
cons: Occasionally there are growing pains. But they are usually worked through pretty quickly.

title: District Manager
pros: The culture is outstanding. Everyone works together and upward mobility is everywhere. You can truly move up as high as you want. The company identifies, develops and promotes talent from within. They will supply you with all the tools you need to succeed.
cons: I can't really think of any. With the constant growth we are experiencing there is a great deal of change that occurs. You have to be ready for new and exciting things.

title: Great Company to work for!
pros: This is a great company to work for! I have been in retail for 10+ years both sales and customer service. Extra Space Storage has been a great breath of fresh air. It is such a united/team environment. Everyone is understanding, supportive and helpful. Every year there are times that take place where you can actually get together with others in your area to help each other learn, grow and have a little fun! I would definitely recommend Extra Space Storage.
cons: At this time in my opinion, there are no cons about working with Extra Space Storage.

title: Excellent place to work
pros: The company culture here is amazing, this is a place where not only do you feel valued as an employee, but you also feel like your opinions and ideas matter. Upper management and peers are fun and enjoyable to work with.
cons: The work at times can be stressful, however, it is not overly so and management takes care to keep on the lookout for employee burnout and to take action to prevent it.

title: District Manager
pros: The culture is by far the best PRO that this organization has. Everyone is extremely genuine in regards to caring for people and it is evident that this is driven from the top down.
cons: To be honest, I really don't have any Con's. I am extremely happy in the role and feel supported by the organization. I am extremely honored to serve my team and look forward to helping them grow from a development standpoint.

title: A janitorial job with sales
pros: A lot of down time You mostly work alone Not a difficult job Pay is decent for what you actually do
cons: You clean 90% of the time especially if you work at an outdoor facility The customers are crazier than other industries They are very strict on the "sales process" which is really you being dishonest in order to sell their insurance to customers You get frequent secret shoppers which aren't graded fairly The company will always take the customers word over yours They claim you can move up in the company but they always higher upper management from the outside

title: Good But No Growth and Fake Feedback
pros: Good pay for someone starting and great supervisors
cons: Higher management is completely deaf to feedback from employees and make very little improvements. They will pretend to listen and take in information ut nothing will change and they will go ahead with what they where already planning as if no feedback was ever given.

title: Great company to work for. One big team.
pros: Great place to work, always challenging lots of change and growth. I have been been here many years and its a very proud company and always striving to do it better than the next guy.
cons: Everyone is overloaded in there job task very demanding most of the time.

title: Not All I thought it should be
pros: Good work schedule if not salary worker Good people to work with (Below DM Level) Performance incentives
cons: DM's usually don't appreciate the work that you do More recognition is given for favoritism than actual work There is a disconnect from worker to upper management once you get past the DM position

title: Money Isn't Everything
pros: Extra Space is a very positive company to work for, very high morale. It is also very healthy financially. You can sense a very strong future. Customer service and customer satisfaction is the primary focus.
cons: The pay is a bit low, I work here despite the pay. This will be the only reason I move on to another job--not being able to afford to work here.

title: Could be better, could be worse
pros: If you have a good rental month, you can end up with a decent bonus, of course, it isn't something you can depend on, as there are plenty of slower months where your threshold to bonus is much too high to actually make anything.
cons: Scrubbing units in the bitter cold mid winter, or in extreme heat during the summer can be difficult. You will be expected to do everything on site depending on your DM to save costs, so be prepared to do all the maintenance, painting, etc. on your own, no one is paying a contractor to fix your site barring extreme circumstances. Although I was initially took the job because they made clear the promotion potential, and their focus on promoting from within, I have noticed in the last year that all of the corporate positions filled (DM, DLM, etc.), have been filled by people not only brand new to Extra Space, but brand new to storage in general. This is extremely discouraging to me and many others, as we expected that putting in the time and work would result in us moving up and ultimately in the company gaining more qualified individuals. Very high turnover, while perhaps not every district has this problem, we are constantly losing people. Every time we hire an employee, or two, one, or two employees quit. Many have taken better positions elsewhere, some just don't seem to expect the amount of physical labor required for the job, either way, people are constantly leaving, meaning those of us that stay are also constantly training.

title: Great company with a great culture
pros: A very open and positive work environment that encourages everyone from the bottom up to share best practices. The ever changing pace of retail but with none of the late night floor sets or black Friday craziness. A company that actually listens to it's people.
cons: with the company putting so much value on getting input from multiple sources it can take longer for big decisions to be made.

title: Good Place to work
pros: Great work/family balance with the hours you work, higher then expected pay for the job, off every Sunday, upper managers generally seem interested in staff problems.
cons: I don't have any complaints about it, I love it here. but it's not for everyone. A lot of cold calling people who signed up online but only had a passing interest in a unit or just shopping around for now, a lot of cleaning and not a lot of customer interaction if you came from standard retail.

title: Wage
pros: Decent wage to start if you need something full-time and stable. Teaches you about business growth. YoY
cons: Wage does not reflect the amount of work and overall stress involved with the job. Only real benefit is for the live-on site mangers. Which in turn makes you comfortable while also not learning anything new beyond the aspect of the job.

title: Only care about bottom line, not field employees
pros: None, unless you like being forced to come in and work during a pandemic around people.
cons: CEO said that ESS will be business as usual during COVID-19 pandemic and stores will only close if government mandates it. While salaried managers and office employees get to work from home, those in the field will be cleaning more and expected to show up and potentially be exposed to an extremely contagious virus. They have the gall to say they care about employees yet don't want to help them and their communities with community spread by shutting down for at least a couple of weeks. Unbelievable.

title: Company Review
pros: The company cares about their employees and the job is fun.
cons: The managers are put in a bad spot by upper management to be the bad guys. ESS is a very greedy company towards their tenants with constant rate increases, high late fee penalties and over priced merchandise. They push the property to hit certain metrics each month, some reasonable and some that are not. Relationship with tenants is very forced in a corporate sense, making them buy insurance and incessantly calling them.

title: Used to be better
pros: This really is a relatively simple job and I like how we are not micromanaged by upper management (for the most part). They are a large company so job security is nice.
cons: the new CEO has been trying to reinvent the storage wheel. It is clear he cares more about his shareholders then his employees. They have been cutting hours more and more and more for each site calling it "smart staffing" where there used to be 2 employees per site daily now I am working alone daily for weeks at a time. This isn't due to lack of employees this is by design. They also expect the same level of cleanliness and service as when there were 2 employees even though I am single coverage every single day I'm working. So twice the workload with the same pay. Unfortunately this company is turning into a greedy corporate powerhouse. I literally heard the CEO tell us our revenue goal was "this" and we beat that by 4% but the shareholders are used to us beating it by 7% so we have to work harder. After that meeting is when I saw them cutting employee hours and even start shutting down certain sites one day during the week to save on costs. This company no longer has its employees best interest at heart which is sad since we are the ones making this company run. It used to be so much better.

title: Great company culture and fun job
pros: Work life balance Incentives, Awards, Bonuses on top of regular pay Recognition between coworkers make it a fun day Impressive uniform allowance shoes and shirts and other merch annually Plenty of growth opportunities, diverse management team and opportunities. Recession proof industry
cons: days are usually either very hectic or very slow Sometimes have to work outside in bad weather if a customer comes in

title: Going From Good to Great
pros: * Autonomy to make decisions at a local level (empowerment). * There are many wonderful, caring and inclusive operational leaders in the company who provide an extraordinary employee experience. * The company strives to provide good service to external customers by hiring good people and continually innovating technology. * Most locations are closed Sundays (work/life balance). * Competitive compensation: salary + bonus + vacation + medical benefits * The company is financially strong/stable and is continually growing, providing opportunities for promotion/personal growth.
cons: * Executive and Senior leaders do not routinely engage with field level employees. And when they do, there is very limited follow-through on topics raised by employees in Field Management Calls or regional Town Hall meetings. * Core Values (Integrity, Passion, Excellence, Innovation and Teamwork) are mentioned in company communications and annual employee performance reviews, but it is unclear what steps senior executives take to monitor/ensure operational leadership (SVPs, DVPs and DMs) are living the values. * The company's Diversity & Inclusion initiative seems somewhat ornamental. The board of directors, executive team, and senior leaders (SVPs and DVPs) are primarily white and/or men. * Executives and senior leaders rarely seek critical feedback. And the company does not ensure a safe environment in which to do so. * Division Vice Presidents and District Managers have great power within their operational environment, with little oversight from the executive team. This can (and has) lead to the formation and perpetuation of operational 'fiefdoms'. * The company limits communication about rate increases to customers via a non-descript postcard (easily mistaken as junk mail), rather than using SMS/email communications (as they do for marketing and past due payments). This creates frequent, unnecessary challenges for front line employees who take the brunt of customer complaints. * The career path to positions DM and above are vague/opaque. The company does not explain how employees are selected for career development, and does not specifically define the qualities and capabilities required for promotion to leadership positions.

title: Great Company To Work For
pros: Extra space storage has a lot of pros in it. My personal best pro is that its a close nit family and they are willing to help or assist you in anything you could imagine.
cons: from my time spent in extra space storage I have not encountered anything I would consider a con.

title: Great place to build a career
pros: Self managed, self driven, property management and paid time off. Flexible long hours and opportunities for growth. It's a great place to build and sharpen your business skills and a career.
cons: if you're not much of a commuter, you might not like this job. Traveling is a part of it and it helps develop your skills from other managers in the company to reach our goals.

title: might want to keep looking
pros: i loved who i used to work with. they are all gone now.
cons: i saw it go full circle which means it doesnt get better but just repeats itself. goes from bad to worse to bad to worse.

title: Great Company to work for if you want a Strong Happy balance between your Career and Life
pros: Since day one I have seen the outstanding happy culture this company offers. When a person is working hard on their career it can be hard to balance out life, and family. I have found that this company allows you to balance out your career and life much easier than any other companies I have worked for. The culture around here is great because people are willing to help everyone succeed no matter what position they are in; we all work hard together as a team. It is very important that everyone has a passion for what they do and works professionally, but it is also just as important that everyone is happy everyday. I absolutely love the company and department activities we do. This makes us all work harder and feel more like a huge family rather than just a big corporation.
cons: The only cons I can think of is this company does not offer any sort of tuition reimbursement. I believe this could help keep more employees work harder at furthering their career with Extra Space. I also believe they should have some sort of a system to help employees move up in positions so everyone is always working hard at that goal, and knows there is actually an end in sight to finally be promoted. This way employees are not just working for years waiting for a position to become available. I believe too many employees move on because promotions do not happen quick enough for some of them or they find better paying careers.

title: Care, appreciate, inform is what they want you to do....seriously they gave it to us on a key chain.
pros: I'm a 37 year old female and i've held jobs in many different places and types of companies, most of them more glamorous than this one. However this has been not only my favorite job, but my favorite company to work for. I'm a field employee, specifically an on-site manager. If you don't like change and constant improvement and you don't like to get in and get your hands a little dirty, this may not be the job for you. We are always changing how we do things, new ways to improve and streamline not only our work, but the customer experience. Is this part sales, yes, but we don't just shove product down the customers throat. They teach us to know how to best help people find what they need and give that to them. There's a little bit of everything to do at an on-site job. You of course sell, you rent units, you sell merchandise, you take payments ect. You also clean, paint, handle some maintenance and get to move around a lot, often outside. I love education they provide and enjoy the people I work with. You work as a team with other sites in your district, but also get to self motivate and work on your own sometimes. There are great incentives, contests, good pay and benefits. They encourage a healthy balance of work and personal life, they also have a yearly fit program to encourage a healthy lifestyle. Company itself continues to grow and I have no worry about job security.
cons: No cons really, I don't know what it's like to work in other districts as i've been at my site for 4 years.

title: Great Place to Work
pros: I am loving the culture and the people that I get to work with. I enjoy the property management aspect as well as the customer interactions. The least stressful job I have had the pleasure to work at. I don't have a dull moment, I can be in the office or out on the property so I don't get restless with sitting in front of a computer or too worn out on my feet, it's really the perfect balance. The company is expanding rapidly and there in so much opportunity for growth and advancement as the company acquires what looks like 30 new sites a month. There are also many Live on Site apartments for store managers at some locations. What a great boon to help their employees live a more balanced life and save money to buy a house, save for their kids college in the future, etc.
cons: The cons would have to be the pay. In the DC suburbs, I get paid $1 more than I did as a cashier at REI over the holiday season. That gives me the incentive to move into a store manager position as quickly as possible but that pay is really only $2 more an hour. They make up for the low pay with monthly bonuses based on the properties performance and number of new rentals. The SMs obviously get the better deal with 30% off the top and the rest split between the ASM and the SM by hours worked. This is great and I am thankful for the bonuses (also more incentive to get promoted asap for the better end of the bonus lol) but with inflation on the rise, gas almost $5 a gallon and food prices sky rocketing, the pay means I work a second side hustle bc the cost of everything looks bleak. I want to stay and I hope they make it easier to bc it is a great company and I'm happier than I've been working in years

title: Assistant Manager
pros: Good company and friendly co-workers. A lot of downtime to play Candy Crush and check Facebook. Closed on Sundays so you can watch football.
cons: The pay is not good at all $13.00 an hour for an Assistant Manager. Assistant Manager is not really a manager because an Assistant Manager is the lowest man on the totem pole. Pushing insurance on new customer and ripping them off. No room to really move up unless you want to relocate.

title: Resources and pace of a high-tech company
pros: Top-notch culture, cutting-edge tech, modern office space, fun and exciting place to work. It's a recession-resistant industry that has done well during the age of COVID-19. It's also the largest, publicly-traded company HQ'd in Salt Lake...insane market cap of close to 15 billion! It really is a hidden-gem in the Salt Lake Valley, especially for tech workers
cons: It's a growing company, so there are natural growing pains. We've learned a lot over the last several years, and we learn from our mistakes.

title: Don‚Äôt look to grow from within.
pros: The bonus structure is fair, the more units you rent them more you can make.
cons: If you‚Äôre a field worker, District Team Lead, Site Manager or Assistant Manager, that‚Äôs all you‚Äôll ever be. They hire distric managers solely from the outside, stating you need multi-site management experience to be considered for a DMiT or DM position, but they will not let you manager multi sites to get that experience until you‚Äôre a DMIT or DM. So they use a catch 22 to keep their good talent / money makers where they want them.

title: Employment Review
pros: Great place to work! Pay is fair. Hours are good.
cons: Need more "paid off holidays". Some facilities need two employees at all times, overwhelming at times with one employee.

title: Great Place to Work
pros: Corporate Leadership- it feels like the top brass understand that the frontline employees are valuable, and are the face of the company. Compensation - Very good compensation for the positions in my opinion, I have never once said " They don't pay me enough to do that" Work/life balance - Very good, no nights , every Sunday off. I would prefer to have 2 days off per week in a row, but am appreciative of having every other Monday off as my husband is a truck driver on the road for 2 weeks at a time. I would never get to see him otherwise so I am very grateful.
cons: Pretty much the same as with any company - Lower level leadership is a popularity contest and very much like junior high. If you are your Dm's favorite you can do/say anything regardless of actual facts and or truth to the matter. Trying to address performance issues is not worth the effort and stress if you are not part of "the in crowd". It is much easier to keep your mouth shut and just redo the work of others. Love my JOB, but there is no communication at the local level, attendance is not monitored nor addressed, advancement opportunities are great - again, if you are part of " The in crowd".

title: Hard work but rewarding
pros: Advancement opportunities are available for those who work hard and stand out above the rest. You can quickly advance through the company. Majority of District managers are fair and understanding but expect you to give 110%. Compensation is fair especially if provided with an apartment. The day to day operations of the store can be hard work and very stressful but rewarding when goals are met and advancements are made.
cons: Work every Saturday, there has to be an opening before you can advance and some employees get restless waiting for their opportunity.

title: Great company to work for.
pros: I have worked for Extra Space for over 10 years. The work culture at this company is very slanted towards doing what is best for the employees. We have multiple recognition rewards and programs. I have witnessed store managers promoted up through the company to become Divisional Vice-presidents.
cons: I would like to see the store manager pay be tied more closely to the revenue volume of the facility they manage. Off site manager pay does not compensate fully when compared to on site managers.

title: Property Accountant
pros: Provides an opportunity to diversify yourself in many areas of Accounting. A company that continues to grow and provide opportunity for internal promotions.
cons: The employee retention rate is very poor. Partially due to and environment where value is not recognized, a difficult feeling of trust amongst upper management, a lot of micro managing from the supervisor level, low pay compared to the market, and a high work load,

title: Overall Great Place To Work!
pros: I feel that the people and culture are the core of this organization. Executives truly want to know how you feel and what you think. Extra Space is a place where you want to come to work...you don't feel like you have to!
cons: I don't have anything to add to "Cons".

title: A good company, but a lot of micro managing
pros: Great work life balance, steady pay with bonus (not much), for the most part a great chance to move up in the company, steady work, and a good way into property management.
cons: Low end of pay but not terrible, high priced insurance (very high priced) for bad plans, a lot of micro managing, low accruing pto, and a lot of going back on words.

title: Increasingly Disappointed
pros: They offer competitive benefits, and per rental bonuses. Work hours are decent. Often get to work with amazing people. Employee discounts on unit rentals and merchandise. Relatively no micromanagement. Live on site options at certain locations.
cons: Store employees are not prioritized, and sometimes treated as replaceable. Pay is not really equal to the amount of work recquired from you. Sometimes end up working by yourself for months on end because of staffing shortage. The amount of pressure placed on managers for performance is truly excesive when considering pay and constant staffing issues. You are harassed if not meeting metrics. They promote themselves as having work/life balance but that is subject to change upon the company's whim. They are not handling COVID properly, and even forced us to work Sundays for 2-3 months to make up for the lost income during the first months of the pandemic. Employees that expressed concerns when being asked to work all 7 days a week during the pandemic where misstreated and disregarded. People working Sundays got reduced hours, or had to use personal leave time to make up for it. No risk pay, and only paid leave when COVID positive. Changes are made abrutly constantly with no forewarning the majority of the time. Training is more than lacking, only 1-2 weeks of training with a Lead, and then moved to the store for the Manager to make up for the rest.
